# Hong Kong's Status as an International Financial Centre

Hong Kong maintains its position as a global offshore RMB business hub. Tax revisions last year have created a favorable environment to attract multinational companies to establish treasury centers in Hong Kong. To develop Hong Kong into an infrastructure financing center and a fintech hub, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) established the Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office (IFFO) and the Fintech Facilitation Office during the year. Within the year, the HKMA granted 13 licenses to providers of stored-value payment instruments. Hong Kong's sound fiscal performance and substantial net external asset position continue to be recognized by credit rating agencies, with Standard & Poor's maintaining its AAA rating for Hong Kong.

# Overview

Due to volatility in global financial markets and uncertainty regarding the RMB exchange rate outlook, offshore RMB activities globally slowed down in 2016. Despite this, Hong Kong maintained its position as the global offshore RMB business hub, handling approximately 70% of global RMB payment transactions. The Shenzhen-Hong Kong Stock Connect mechanism was launched in December, marking another milestone in the opening of mainland capital accounts and an important step in enhancing Hong Kong's status as an international financial center. The HKMA also strengthened financial infrastructure by expanding RMB liquidity support to the market and implementing measures to increase transparency in the RMB market.

The HKMA established the Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office (IFFO) in July to promote infrastructure development through the aggregation of major stakeholders and to develop Hong Kong as an infrastructure financing center. As of January 2017, over 60 institutions had joined IFFO as partners. During the year, the HKMA successfully promoted the passage of legislative amendments to eliminate tax asymmetries and provide tax incentives, encouraging multinational and mainland companies to establish treasury centers in Hong Kong, bringing more business opportunities to the financial and professional services sectors. The number of institutional investors operating in Hong Kong has gradually increased, with the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority, the third-largest sovereign wealth fund in the world, announcing the establishment of an overseas office in Hong Kong in October – the only one outside Abu Dhabi.

The International Monetary Fund (IMF) gave a positive evaluation of our efforts to consolidate Hong Kong's position as an international financial center during the fourth Article consultation last year. Throughout the year, the HKMA actively participated in international discussions to advance global and regional financial stability. The HKMA also maintained close communication with international credit rating agencies, and this work helped confirm Hong Kong's credit ratings by major credit rating agencies in 2016.

The safe and efficient operation and continuous development of Hong Kong's financial infrastructure play an important role in consolidating Hong Kong's competitiveness as an international financial center and global offshore RMB business hub. Four real-time gross settlement (RTGS) systems used for inter-bank transactions and the Debt Instruments Clearing and Settlement System (CMU system) achieved 100% system availability in 2016, exceeding the target level of 99.95%.

In 2016, the HKMA further enhanced Hong Kong's retail payment financial infrastructure. A total of 13 stored-value payment instrument licenses were issued according to the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance (Payment Ordinance), which came into full effect in November 2016. The scope of electronic cheque services was also extended to cross-border payments between Hong Kong and Guangdong Province (including Shenzhen).

To promote the development of fintech in Hong Kong, the HKMA established the Fintech Facilitation Office in March. Several significant measures implemented during the year achieved ideal progress.

The HKMA introduced a series of measures to strengthen the soft power of the banking sector, including (i) launching the Professional Capacity Enhancement Programme for Directors; (ii) establishing an industry-wide framework for the professional qualifications of banking personnel; and (iii) implementing consumer education programmes.

# Review of 2016

# Offshore RMB Activities

Volatility in global financial markets and uncertainty regarding the RMB exchange rate outlook led to a slowdown in offshore RMB activities in 2016. By year-end, the combined balance of RMB customer deposits and deposit certificates in Hong Kong amounted to RMB625.1 billion, a decrease of 38% compared to the previous year (Figure 1). The issuance volume of offshore RMB bonds fell to RMB52.8 billion during the year, and the RMB trade settlement amount processed by Hong Kong banks also dropped to RMB4,542.1 billion. On the other hand, the RMB loan balance of Hong Kong banks by year-end reached RMB294.8 billion, remaining similar to the previous year (Figure 2). The transaction volume of the RMB RTGS system remained high, with an average daily processing amount of RMB863.6 billion in 2016. This shows that despite the reduction in the RMB fund pool, it continues to support extensive RMB financial intermediary activities in Hong Kong. According to SWIFT statistics, Hong Kong handled approximately 70% of RMB payment transactions in 2016, demonstrating its position as the global offshore RMB business hub.

Figure 2 RMB Financing Activities

During the year, the HKMA worked closely with relevant authorities in the mainland to secure greater policy space to promote Hong Kong's RMB business. Multiple new measures were introduced, including further expansion of access to the mainland interbank bond market and foreign exchange market, as well as the launch of the "Shenzhen-Hong Kong Stock Connect" in December. In response to the growing demand for cross-border investment channels and liquidity management, the HKMA expanded its RMB liquidity arrangements. In October, the number of primary liquidity providers was increased from seven to nine, and the total quota of the scheme was raised from RMB14 billion to RMB18 billion. Transparency in the usage of the HKMA's RMB liquidity arrangements was also improved, helping participants manage liquidity more effectively.

The National "13th Five-Year Plan" published in March once again affirmed Hong Kong's position as the global offshore RMB business hub, indicating the central government's support for Hong Kong's further development of offshore RMB business.

At the same time, the HKMA continued to enhance cooperation with other economies to develop offshore RMB business. The HKMA actively participated in various activities to promote Hong Kong's role as the main platform for the "going out strategy" of the mainland, including participating in industry organizations and private sector events locally, as well as overseas events in China, Germany, Kazakhstan, and the UK.

# Closer Economic and Trade Relationship Arrangement between the Mainland and Hong Kong

Under the framework of the Closer Economic and Trade Relationship Arrangement between the Mainland and Hong Kong, a new agreement on the basic realization of service trade liberalization between the Mainland and Hong Kong was signed in 2015. The HKMA continues to closely monitor the implementation of existing measures under the current arrangement and cooperate with government authorities to explore progressive expansion of market access and facilitation measures for Hong Kong's financial industry.

# Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office (IFFO)

# Mission of IFFO

The mission of IFFO is to promote infrastructure investment and financing by aggregating major stakeholders. The functions of IFFO include:
- Providing a platform for information exchange and experience sharing;
- Enhancing skills and knowledge in infrastructure investment and financing;
- Promoting market and product development;
- And facilitating infrastructure investment and financing activities.

Mr. Paul Chan, Chief Executive of the HKMA (7th from left), toasts with other guests at the IFFO launch ceremony.

The HKMA established IFFO in July, whose mission is to promote infrastructure investment and financing by aggregating major stakeholders. As of January 2017, over 60 institutions from the mainland, Hong Kong, and overseas had joined IFFO as partners, including multilateral financial institutions and development banks, public sector investors, private sector investors, asset management companies, banks, insurance companies, infrastructure project developers and operators, professional service firms, and the International Chamber of Commerce (Table 1).

Since its establishment, IFFO has made good progress. To enhance skills, IFFO co-hosted an executive workshop with the International Finance Corporation, part of the World Bank Group, and Hanwha Asset Management in October, focusing on "Investment and Financing of Infrastructure Projects in Emerging Markets with Private Capital." The workshop received very positive feedback from participants, helping to expand knowledge and build networks. IFFO also held a senior-level seminar in November, inviting Mr. Jin Liqun, President of the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, to share his experience in infrastructure project planning, operation, and management. In July, IFFO signed Memoranda of Understanding (MoUs) with the International Finance Corporation and the Global Infrastructure Facility to establish a cooperation framework. In December, MoUs were also signed with the China Development Bank and the Export-Import Bank of China to promote infrastructure project financing of these two banks through the IFFO platform. These activities help strengthen Hong Kong's position and international image as an infrastructure financing center.

Mr. Paul Chan, Chief Executive of the HKMA (left front), signs an MoU with Mr. Philippe Le Houérou, Executive Vice President and CEO of the International Finance Corporation (right front), to facilitate cooperation using the IFFO platform to create a more efficient and conducive market environment for regional infrastructure investment and financing.

Mr. Paul Chan, Chief Executive of the HKMA (left front), signs an MoU with Mr. Chris Heathcote, CEO of the Global Infrastructure Facility (right front), to establish a strategic cooperation framework to promote infrastructure project financing.

Mr. Paul Chan, Chief Executive of the HKMA (left), signs an MoU with Mr. Hu Huabang, Chairman of the China Development Bank, to strengthen cooperation between the bank and the HKMA.

# Treasury Centers

To further attract multinational companies to set up treasury centers in Hong Kong, the HKMA collaborated with government authorities to create a favorable tax environment for treasury centers. Specifically, the "Taxation (Amendment No. 2) Ordinance 2016" was passed in June, allowing companies to deduct interest expenses related to group internal financing when calculating profits tax, provided they meet specified conditions. Additionally, profits from qualified treasury centers' designated treasury-related businesses would be subject to a 50% concessionary profits tax rate (reduced to 8.25%). Table 2 summarizes some key points of the Amendment Ordinance:

In addition to legislative work, the HKMA actively promotes the advantages of setting up treasury centers in Hong Kong to multinational and mainland companies. By year-end, the HKMA had engaged nearly 400 companies, financial institutions, and industry organizations. The HKMA also signed an MoU with the Hong Kong Chinese Enterprises Association in November to help Hong Kong-based Chinese enterprises better understand and utilize our treasury center platform.

# Promotion of Asset Management Business

The HKMA continues to promote Hong Kong as an asset management center. According to the Securities and Futures Commission (SFC), the number of licensed entities engaged in asset management reached 1,300 at the end of 2016, an increase of nearly 15% year-on-year. According to the Asia Venture Capital Journal, the number of private equity fund companies in Hong Kong (including SFC-licensed and non-SFC-licensed entities) also increased by 4.6% to 431 in 2016. So far, nearly 70 of the world's top 100 asset management companies, as well as most of the top 20 mainland mutual fund companies, have established operations or affiliated companies in Hong Kong. The number of institutional investors operating in Hong Kong has also gradually increased, with the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority, the third-largest sovereign wealth fund in the world, announcing the establishment of an overseas office in Hong Kong in October – the only one outside Abu Dhabi.

# Introduction of Open-ended Fund Company Structure

To attract funds to register in Hong Kong, the HKMA continues to collaborate with the government and the industry to create a more favorable tax and regulatory environment. In June, the "Securities and Futures (Amendment) Bill 2016" was passed, introducing the open-ended fund company structure, making Hong Kong's fund registration platform more diversified and creating a more flexible operating environment for fund managers, thereby strengthening Hong Kong's competitiveness as an international asset management center.

# Islamic Finance

The HKMA continues to increase market awareness and understanding of Islamic finance, including organizing and participating in Islamic finance seminars and lectures together with industry associations, and sharing experiences in issuing Islamic bonds with market participants to encourage them to use Hong Kong's platform. Following the successful issuance of the previous two tranches of Islamic bonds, the HKMA has been working closely with the government to launch the third tranche of Islamic bonds when market conditions are suitable.

# 儲備管理

2016年是充滿意外和黑天鵝事件的一年，環球金融市場出現大波動和震盪。2016年年初市場憂慮內地經濟硬着陸及全球增長放緩，促使環球股市大幅下挫。6月英國脫歐公投和11月美國大選結果亦出人意表。儘管投資環境困難，金管局在過去幾年已採取連串防禦措施，增強外匯基金的抗震能力，因此外匯基金在2016年仍錄得2% 的整體投資回報。

# 外匯基金

根據《外匯基金條例》，外匯基金的首要目的是直接或間接影響港元匯價，亦可運用於保持香港貨幣及金融體系穩定健全，藉此保持香港作為國際金融中心的地位。外匯基金由財政司司長掌有控制權，並投資於其經諮詢外匯基金諮詢委員會後認為合適的證券或其他資產。

# 外匯基金的管理

# 投資目標及組合結構

外匯基金諮詢委員會為外匯基金制定下列投資目標：
(a) 保障資本；
(b) 確保整體貨幣基礎在任何時候都由流通性極高的美元資產提供十足支持；
(c) 確保流動資金足以維持貨幣及金融穩定；以及
(d) 在符合上述(a)至(c)項的前提下盡量爭取投資回報，以保障基金的長期購買力。

以上目標全面顧及外匯基金的法定目的，並已於外匯基金的組合結構及目標資產分布中反映。

外匯基金大致上分成兩個主要組合：支持組合及投資組合。支持組合持有流通性極高的美元資產，按照貨幣發行局制度的規定為貨幣基礎提供十足支持。投資組合主要投資於經濟合作與發展組織成員國的債市及股市，以保障資產的價值及長期購買力。這兩個組合整體債券與股票的長線目標分布比率為71比29。以目標貨幣比重計，91%的資產分配予美元及港元，其餘9%分配予其他貨幣。

為能更妥善管理風險及提高中長期回報，金管局以審慎及循序漸進方式將外匯基金的部分資產分散投資至較多元化的資產類別，包括新興巿場及內地債券與股票、私募股權，以及海外投資物業。新興巿場及內地債券與股票由投資組合持有，私募股權及房地產投資則由長期增長組合持有。長期增長組合的市值上限為外匯基金累計盈餘的三分之一，但因應部分未來基金投放於長期資產，市值上限還有增加的空間。

策略性資產組合於2007年設立，以持有政府基於策略性目的而為外匯基金帳目購入的香港交易及結算所有限公司股份。由於這個組合性質獨特，因此外匯基金的投資表現評估並無將其包括在內。

# 於外匯基金的存款

外匯基金不時接受財政儲備、政府基金及法定組織的存款，利率一般與投資組合的表現掛鈎2，惟未來基金存款則除外。未來基金存款的利率與投資組合及長期增長組合的表現掛鈎，實際利率視乎組合比重而定。於2016年底，未來基金在投資組合與長期增長組合的比重為80：20。預期截至2018年底，未來基金存款中與長期增長組合掛鈎的部分會逐步增加至約50%。

# 投資程序

外匯基金的投資程序分別以策略性資產分布及戰略性資產分布作基礎。策略性資產分布，即投資基準反映的分布情況，顯示外匯基金為達到投資目標而可以作出的最佳長線資產分布。外匯基金以策略性分布作為指引，對資產進行戰略性分布，以爭取超越基準的回報。因此，實際分布往往會與基準分布（亦即策略性分布）有所偏離，而實際與基準分布之間的差距稱為「戰略性偏離」。財政司司長經諮詢外匯基金諮詢委員會後制定投資基準及戰略性偏離的限度，金管局獲授權決定戰略性資產分布。投資組合經理可在戰略性偏離的限度內選持倉盤，從短期市場變化中獲利。

# 投資管理

# 直接投資

金管局儲備管理部職員直接管理外匯基金約74%的投資，其中包括整個支持組合及部分投資組合。該部分投資組合投資於環球定息市場，並透過衍生工具執行外匯基金的宏觀風險管理策略。

# 外聘投資經理

除透過內部職員管理資產外，金管局亦僱用外聘投資經理負責管理外匯基金約26%的資產，其中包括所有上市股票組合及其他特別資產。僱用外聘投資經理的目的，是要運用市場上最佳的專業投資技術為外匯基金投資，並讓外匯基金受惠於多元化的投資方式，以及讓內部專業人員汲取市場知識與資訊。

僱用外聘投資經理的相關支出包括基金管理與託管費、交易費、預扣稅及其他稅項。這些支出主要受市場因素影響而每年不同。

金管局支持證券及期貨事務監察委員會於2016年3月7日發布的《負責任的擁有權原則》（《原則》）。《原則》屬自願性質，旨在協助投資者釐定如何以最佳方法履行其於香港上市公司的投資的擁有權責任。就外匯基金的管理而言，金管局鼓勵獲委任負責管理香港股票組合的外聘基金經理在管理有關投資時採納《原則》。

# 風險管理及監察

近年金融市場波動極大，凸顯風險管理的重要。金管局為內部及外聘投資經理所管理的投資組合均訂立嚴格管控措施及投資指引，並密切監察對指引及法規的遵守情況；另亦採用風險管控工具來評估在正常及極度不利市況下的市場風險。金管局亦進行詳細的投資表現因素分析，務求能最有效地運用內部及外聘投資經理的投資管理技術。

# 2016年的金融市場

2016年環球金融市場出現大波動和震盪。股票市場方面，1月市場憂慮內地經濟硬着陸及全球增長放緩，促使香港及其他主要股市大幅下挫，直至2月中旬市場才穩定下來。6月英國脫歐公投及11月美國大選結果相繼出人意表，但股市在經歷短暫下挫後迅速收復失地。全年計，環球股市普遍表現理想。

債券市場方面，第1季商品價格進一步下跌加深市場對全球增長放緩及低通脹的憂慮，加上第2季英國脫歐公投帶來的不明朗因素及市場對中央銀行維持寬鬆政策的預期，加大了市場對安全資產的需求，支持政府債市於2016年上半年有不俗表現。其中10年期美國國庫券收益率在7月跌至1.36%的歷史低位。然而，在下半年由於市場對美國加息的預期升溫，尤其在美國總統選舉後，美國國庫券收益率飆升。其他主要政府債券的收益率亦上升，但升幅較小。

# Reserve Management

2016 was a year marked by unexpected events and black swan incidents, with significant fluctuations and volatility in global financial markets. At the beginning of 2016, market concerns over the possibility of a hard landing in the mainland economy and slowing global growth led to sharp declines in global stock markets. The UK referendum on EU membership in June and the unexpected results of the US presidential election in November also caused market shocks. Despite the challenging investment environment, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) had implemented a series of defensive measures in recent years to enhance the resilience of the Exchange Fund. As a result, the Exchange Fund achieved an overall investment return of 2% in 2016.

# Exchange Fund

Under the Exchange Fund Ordinance, the primary objective of the Exchange Fund is to directly or indirectly influence the exchange rate of the Hong Kong dollar, and it may also be used to maintain the stability and soundness of Hong Kong's monetary and financial system, thereby preserving Hong Kong's status as an international financial centre. The Exchange Fund is under the control of the Financial Secretary and is invested in securities or other assets deemed appropriate by the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee after consultation.

# Management of the Exchange Fund

# Investment Objectives and Portfolio Structure

The Exchange Fund Advisory Committee has set the following investment objectives for the Exchange Fund:
(a) To preserve capital;
(b) To ensure that the entire monetary base is fully supported at all times by highly liquid U.S. dollar assets;
(c) To ensure sufficient liquidity to maintain monetary and financial stability; and
(d) To strive for investment returns within the framework of the above (a) to (c), in order to safeguard the long-term purchasing power of the Fund.

These objectives comprehensively reflect the statutory purposes of the Exchange Fund and have been reflected in the portfolio structure and target asset allocation of the Exchange Fund.

The Exchange Fund is generally divided into two main portfolios: the supporting portfolio and the investment portfolio. The supporting portfolio holds highly liquid U.S. dollar assets, providing full support for the monetary base according to the requirements of the Currency Board system. The investment portfolio mainly invests in the bond and equity markets of Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) member countries to safeguard the value and long-term purchasing power of the assets. The long-term target distribution ratio of bonds and equities in these two portfolios is 71 to 29. In terms of target currency weights, 91% of the assets are allocated to the U.S. dollar and Hong Kong dollar, with the remaining 9% allocated to other currencies.

To better manage risks and improve medium-to-long-term returns, the HKMA has gradually diversified the allocation of some of the Exchange Fund's assets into more diverse asset classes, including emerging market and mainland China bonds and equities, private equity, and overseas real estate investments. Emerging market and mainland China bonds and equities are held in the investment portfolio, while private equity and real estate investments are held in the long-term growth portfolio. The market value ceiling for the long-term growth portfolio is one-third of the cumulative surplus of the Exchange Fund, but there is still room for expansion given the future allocation of funds to long-term assets.

The Strategic Asset Portfolio was established in 2007 to hold shares in The Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited purchased by the Government for strategic purposes. Due to its unique nature, the performance evaluation of the Exchange Fund does not include this portfolio.

# Deposits in the Exchange Fund

The Exchange Fund occasionally accepts deposits from fiscal reserves, government funds, and statutory organizations, with interest rates typically linked to the performance of the investment portfolio, except for future fund deposits. The interest rate for future fund deposits is linked to the performance of both the investment portfolio and the long-term growth portfolio, with the actual rate depending on the portfolio composition. By the end of 2016, the allocation of future fund deposits between the investment portfolio and the long-term growth portfolio was 80:20. It is expected that by the end of 2018, the portion of future fund deposits linked to the long-term growth portfolio will gradually increase to approximately 50%.

# Investment Procedures

The investment procedures of the Exchange Fund are based on the strategic asset allocation and the tactical asset allocation. The strategic asset allocation, reflecting the distribution shown in the investment benchmark, indicates the optimal long-term asset allocation that the Exchange Fund can adopt to achieve its investment objectives. The Exchange Fund uses the strategic allocation as a guide to make tactical allocations of assets to seek returns exceeding the benchmark. Therefore, the actual allocation often deviates from the benchmark allocation (i.e., the strategic allocation), and the difference between the actual and benchmark allocations is called "tactical deviation." After consulting the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, the Financial Secretary sets the limits for the investment benchmark and tactical deviations, and the HKMA is authorized to determine the tactical asset allocation. Portfolio managers can select holdings within the limits of tactical deviation to profit from short-term market changes.

# Investment Management

# Direct Investments

Approximately 74% of the Exchange Fund's investments are managed directly by the HKMA's Reserve Management Department staff, including the entire supporting portfolio and part of the investment portfolio. This portion of the investment portfolio is invested in the global fixed-income market and executes the Exchange Fund's macro-risk management strategy through derivative instruments.

# External Investment Managers

In addition to managing assets internally, the HKMA employs external investment managers to manage approximately 26% of the Exchange Fund's assets, including all listed equity portfolios and other special assets. The purpose of employing external investment managers is to utilize the best professional investment techniques available in the market for the Exchange Fund's investments, allowing the Exchange Fund to benefit from diversified investment approaches and enabling internal professionals to gain market knowledge and information.

The costs associated with employing external investment managers include fund management and custody fees, transaction costs, withholding taxes, and other taxes. These expenses vary annually due to market factors.

The HKMA supports the Securities and Futures Commission's (SFC) "Principles of Responsible Ownership" issued on March 7, 2016. The Principles are voluntary in nature and aim to help investors determine how to best fulfill their ownership responsibilities regarding investments in Hong Kong-listed companies. Regarding the management of the Exchange Fund, the HKMA encourages externally appointed fund managers responsible for managing the Hong Kong equity portfolio to adopt the Principles when managing those investments.

# Risk Management and Oversight

With the extreme volatility in financial markets in recent years, the importance of risk management has become increasingly evident. The HKMA has established strict control measures and investment guidelines for investment portfolios managed by both internal and external investment managers, and closely monitors compliance with these guidelines and regulations. Additionally, the HKMA uses risk management tools to assess market risks under normal and extremely adverse conditions. The HKMA also conducts detailed analysis of investment performance factors to effectively utilise the investment management skills of both internal and external investment managers.

# Performance of the Exchange Fund

# Financial Markets in 2016

Global financial markets experienced significant fluctuations and volatility in 2016. In the stock market, concerns over a potential hard landing in the mainland economy and slowing global growth in January led to sharp declines in the Hong Kong and other major stock markets, with markets stabilizing only by mid-February. The unexpected outcomes of the UK Brexit referendum in June and the US presidential election in November resulted in temporary market downturns, but stock markets quickly recovered. Throughout the year, global stock markets generally performed well.

In the bond market, falling commodity prices in the first quarter deepened market concerns about slowing global growth and low inflation, while uncertainty arising from the UK Brexit referendum in the second quarter and expectations of continued central bank accommodative policies increased demand for safe assets, resulting in strong performance in government bond markets during the first half of 2016. The yield on the 10-year U.S. Treasury note fell to a historical low of 1.36% in July. However, in the second half of the year, rising expectations of U.S. interest rate hikes, particularly after the U.S. presidential election, caused U.S. Treasury yields to surge. Yields on other major government bonds also increased, although to a lesser extent.

In the money market, the U.S. dollar continued to strengthen in 2016, with the U.S. Dollar Index reaching a high of 14 years. The sustained strength of the U.S. dollar was supported by widening interest rate differentials between the U.S. dollar and other major currencies. Although the Japanese yen appreciated against the U.S. dollar by about 3% in 2016, the euro depreciated against the U.S. dollar by about 3%. Under the ongoing uncertainties caused by the UK Brexit referendum outcome, the British pound declined by 16% against the U.S. dollar during the year, marking the largest decline since 2008.

# Performance of the Exchange Fund

Despite the significant market volatility, the Exchange Fund recorded investment income of HK$68.1 billion in 2016, including HK$28.6 billion from overseas equity investments, HK$5.3 billion from Hong Kong equity investments, HK$33.1 billion from bond investments, HK$16.9 billion from other investments held by subsidiaries of the Exchange Fund's investment holding companies, and a HK$15.8 billion negative foreign exchange valuation adjustment on non-Hong Kong dollar assets. Due to the sharp appreciation of the U.S. dollar last year, the Exchange Fund inevitably experienced a negative foreign exchange valuation adjustment when converting non-U.S. dollar investments into Hong Kong dollars. On the other hand, the strategic asset portfolio recorded a HK$7 billion valuation loss.

By the end of 2016, the total assets of the Exchange Fund reached HK$3,618.7 billion. The total market value of the long-term growth portfolio investments amounted to HK$181.8 billion, including HK$116.8 billion in private equity and HK$65.0 billion in real estate, with a total amount of committed but uninvested capital of HK$133.8 billion.

Despite the continuous challenges in the investment environment, the Exchange Fund achieved an investment return of 2% in 2016 (excluding the strategic asset portfolio). The long-term growth portfolio has delivered an annualised internal return of approximately 12% since its inception in 2009.

Due to the continued deterioration of the external investment environment, the HKMA has made a series of defensive deployments in recent years, including shortening the duration of the bond portfolio, increasing cash holdings, and significantly reducing non-U.S. dollar and non-Hong Kong dollar assets. We have also accelerated our pace of diversification, particularly in the long-term growth portfolio investments. These measures have greatly enhanced the resilience of the Exchange Fund.

金管局與傳媒保持緊密聯繫，以提高金管局的透明度，並增進公眾對其政策和工作的了解。金管局在2016年共進行了81次公開媒體活動，包括14次新聞發布會、13次即場訪問和54次其他公開活動，並安排了30次媒體訪談。年內發布326份雙語新聞稿，每日亦處理大量傳媒查詢。

除金管局《年報》外，金管局於年內出版兩期《貨幣與金融穩定情況半年度報告》及4期《季報》，並定期更新《金融數據月報》資料，提供有關香港貨幣、銀行業及經濟事務的最新及專題資料與分析。此外，金管局在2016年共發表32篇《匯思》文章，較2015年14篇顯著增加，闡析與金管局工作相關的多個專題事項。

金管局《二零一五年年報》在香港管理專業協會2016年度最佳年報評選中獲得「非牟利及慈善機構」類銀獎。

# 公眾教育計劃

金管局資訊中心設於國際金融中心2期55樓，向公眾介紹金管局工作及提高公眾對貨幣與銀行業事宜的了解。資訊中心分為展覽館和圖書館兩部分，每星期6天開放予公眾參觀使用。展覽館介紹金管局的工作，以及香港貨幣與銀行業的發展；另備閱讀資料與展品，供研究香港貨幣、銀行業和金融事務。

資訊中心闡述金管局工作及介紹相關金融知識的政策展區在2016年第4季展開翻新工程，令展覽內容更豐富及加入多種互動元素，特別是加入寓學習於遊玩的互動遊戲，深入淺出地闡明金融概念，又有圖文並茂的輕觸式屏幕，更全面及深入地介紹金管局的工作，務求為訪客帶來全新的參觀體驗。此外，翻新後的資訊中心還有一幅以超過13萬枚香港硬幣砌出維港景色的馬賽克作品。全新形象的政策展區已於2017年2月24日重新開放，供公眾參觀。

# 金管局網站

金管局的機構網站(www.hkma.gov.hk)提供5萬多頁英文及繁簡字體中文版資料，方便公眾查閱金管局的最新資訊。網站另載有根據《銀行業條例》第20條備存的「認可機構證券業務員工紀錄冊」及「認可機構及本地代表辦事處紀錄冊」，以及根據《支付系統及儲值支付工具條例》備存的「儲值支付工具持牌人紀錄冊」。網站特設專題網頁及突出的快速連結，提醒公眾注意金管局的新措施，例如儲值支付工具監管制度、IFFO與FFO，以及重要及適時事項，例如提防電話騙案及硬幣收集計劃收銀車停泊的位置。

# 人力資源

金管局聘用、培訓及維持一支專業優秀的工作隊伍，以履行政策目標及靈活應對工作重點的變化。金管局是政府架構的一部分，但按非公務員條款聘請員工，吸引具適當經驗及專門知識的人才。作為公營機構，金管局致力維持精簡靈活的組織架構，並盡可能透過調配現有人手推行新措施及應付不斷增加的工作量。

# 人手編制

金管局於2016年初的人手編制為875人，2016年下半年增設12個職位，以履行金管局在新保險業監管制度下的監管職能。因此，金管局在2016年底的人手編制為887人。

為確保有足夠資源實行新法例和政策、繼續推進須持續的試行項目，以及處理現有日益繁重和複雜的工作，金管局的整體編制於2017年增加40人至927人（增幅4.5%）。新增職位負責執行以下職能：
- 促進銀行及金融體系穩定，包括：
    - 加強監理能力，以管理銀行日益增加的科技風險及新的金融科技項目，以及應對銀行在區內及業務上的擴展；
    - 加強打擊清洗黑錢及恐怖分子資金籌集活動的監管及執法工作，並為2018年打擊清洗黑錢財務特別行動組織相互評估計劃作好準備；
    - 作好實施《金融機構（處置機制）條例》的規劃及籌備工作，以根據國際標準處理金融業「大到不能倒」的問題；及
    - 加強監理能力以配合有關資本及市場風險的新國際標準，並增撥資源處理消費者保障事宜及銀行投訴。
- 因應進一步推動外匯基金投資產品多元化所牽涉的更多投資工作，加強投資、風險管理及其他相關支援，同時強化策略性資產分配及投資程序，以應對挑戰日增的投資環境。
- 制定及實施人才發展計劃，並加強相關資源，確保金管局具備所需的人力資源應對市場發展及未來的挑戰。
- 加強貨幣政策方面的研究及貨幣統計資料的處理，以及提供資源處理就儲值支付工具及零售支付系統的牌照╱指定及相關監管事宜而作出的查詢及投訴。

# 薪酬福利政策及薪酬檢討機制

財政司司長透過外匯基金諮詢委員會聽取其轄下管治委員會提供的意見，並參考市場薪酬水平及做法，決定金管局員工的薪酬及服務條件。薪酬組合包括現金薪酬及公積金，另設一些基本福利。現金薪酬包括每月固定薪酬（即基本薪酬）及根據員工工作表現每年一次過發放的浮動薪酬。

財政司司長每年檢討金管局員工薪酬時，會透過外匯基金諮詢委員會聽取其轄下管治委員會的建議，並考慮管治委員會對金管局過去一年的表現評估、獨立人力資源顧問公司進行的金融業薪酬調查結果，以及其他相關因素。個別工作表現優秀的員工的薪酬亦可能獲得特別調整，以保持其薪酬競爭力。

金管局按個別員工的工作表現，分配獲批准用作調整年度固定薪酬或發放浮動薪酬的款項；而用於專業投資人員的浮動薪酬制度，則旨在加強其投資表現與薪酬的連繫。助理總裁或以上職級員工的固定薪酬調整或浮動薪酬的發放，是由財政司司長經參考管治委員會的意見後批准，有關員工在會議討論到其薪酬的議案時會避席。主管及以下職級員工的固定薪酬調整或浮動薪酬的發放，則由金管局總裁根據財政司司長授權，並按照獲批准用作支付薪酬的整筆款項來決定。

# Institutional Functions

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) maintains effective communication with society and the market through media, public education initiatives, and various other channels, to enhance public understanding of its policies and operations. Throughout the year, the HKMA continued to strengthen institutional governance, including promoting staff professional development, strictly controlling finances, and enhancing information technology security, to address challenges arising from implementing new measures and increasing workloads.

# Maintaining Communication with the Public and Institutional Development

# Public Communications

The HKMA maintains close contact with the media to enhance transparency and improve public understanding of its policies and work. In 2016, the HKMA conducted 81 public media activities, including 14 press conferences, 13 live interviews, and 54 other public events, as well as arranged 30 media interviews. A total of 326 bilingual press releases were issued during the year, and numerous media inquiries were handled daily.

During the year, the HKMA established two important offices: the Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office (IFFO) and the Financial Technology Facilitation Office (FFO). To explain their functions and work plans, the HKMA carried out multiple public communication activities. Additionally, the HKMA organized media briefings and seminars to deepen public understanding of its operations and measures in areas such as financial inclusion, reserve management, financial technology regulatory sandbox, cybersecurity, and SME financing.

Mr. Paul Chan, Chief Executive of the HKMA, met with journalists during the annual Beijing trip of the Hong Kong Bankers Association in December 2016.

# Public Enquiries

The public inquiry service provides an effective channel for citizens to obtain information about the HKMA's functions and work. This service processed 10,170 inquiries in 2016, representing a 12% increase compared to 2015. Approximately half of the inquiries concerned banking policies and regulations, monetary and economic matters, and bank consumer issues, particularly bank products and services, coin collection schemes, guidance and notices related to the banking sector, stored value facilities, retail payment systems, anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing efforts, and prudent regulatory measures for mortgage loans.

Figure 1 shows the number of public inquiries received annually since 2013, while Figure 2 lists the proportion of different types of inquiries in 2016.

# Publications

In addition to the HKMA Annual Report, the HKMA published two issues of the Half-Yearly Review of Money and Financial Stability and four issues of the Quarterly Bulletin during the year. The Monthly Financial Data Bulletin was regularly updated to provide the latest and special information and analysis on Hong Kong's monetary, banking, and economic affairs. Furthermore, the HKMA published 32 articles in the "Insight" series in 2016, significantly more than the 14 articles in 2015, covering various topics related to the HKMA's work.

The HKMA's 2015 Annual Report won the Silver Award in the "Non-Profit and Charitable Organizations" category in the 2016 Hong Kong Management Professionals Association Best Annual Reports Awards.

# Public Education Programmes

The HKMA Information Centre, located on the 55th floor of International Finance Centre Phase II, introduces the HKMA's work and enhances public awareness of monetary and banking matters. The centre consists of an exhibition hall and a library, open to the public six days a week. The exhibition hall showcases the HKMA's work and the development of Hong Kong's monetary and banking sectors, with reading materials and exhibits available for research on Hong Kong's monetary, banking, and financial affairs.

The Policy Exhibition Area of the Information Centre underwent renovation in the fourth quarter of 2016, enriching the exhibition content and adding various interactive elements, particularly interactive games that make learning fun, explaining financial concepts in an accessible way, and multimedia touch-screen displays providing comprehensive and in-depth information about the HKMA's work, aiming to offer visitors a brand-new experience. Additionally, the renovated Information Centre features a mosaic artwork made of over 130,000 Hong Kong coins depicting the Victoria Harbour view. The newly rebranded Policy Exhibition Area was reopened to the public on February 24, 2017.

# HKMA Website

The HKMA's institutional website (www.hkma.gov.hk) provides over 50,000 pages of English and traditional/simplified Chinese versions of information, facilitating public access to the latest HKMA information. The site also contains the "Register of Employees of Authorised Institutions Engaged in Securities Business" and the "Register of Authorised Institutions and Local Representative Offices" maintained under Section 20 of the Banking Ordinance, as well as the "Register of Stored Value Facility Licensees" maintained under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance. The website has dedicated web pages and prominent quick links to inform the public about new measures by the HKMA, such as the stored value facility regulatory framework, IFFO and FFO, and important and timely matters, such as preventing telephone frauds and locations of coin collection vehicles.

New look of the Policy Exhibition Area at the Information Centre.

Mosaic artwork made of Hong Kong coins depicting the Victoria Harbour view.

The Information Centre offers guided tours for visitors. During the year, the Information Centre welcomed over 56,200 visitors and provided 580+ guided tours for schools and other groups (Figure 3). Since its launch in December 2003, the Information Centre has cumulatively welcomed over 586,600 visitors.

Adjacent to the exhibition hall, the library houses over 23,000 books, journals, and periodicals for in-depth study of topics relating to Hong Kong's monetary, banking, financial, and central banking affairs. The library also keeps electronic registers of authorised institutions and local representative offices and employees engaged in securities business required under Section 20 of the Banking Ordinance.

To maintain community engagement and enhance public awareness of the HKMA's work, the HKMA continues to hold public education lectures. In 2016, the HKMA held three public lectures attended by over 1,750 secondary school students and teachers, focusing on topics such as the Linked Exchange Rate System, banking system stability, Hong Kong banknotes, smart tips for using banking products and services, and the Deposit Protection Scheme. Since the introduction of the educational lecture programme in 1998, over 56,400 members of the public have participated.

# Human Resources

The HKMA employs, trains, and maintains a professional and excellent workforce to fulfill policy objectives and respond flexibly to changes in work priorities. As part of the Government structure, the HKMA hires staff under non-civil service terms to attract talent with appropriate experience and expertise. As a public institution, the HKMA is committed to maintaining a lean and flexible organizational structure, and strives to implement new measures and cope with increasing workloads by reallocating existing personnel.

# Staffing Structure

At the beginning of 2016, the HKMA had a staffing structure of 875 people. In the second half of 2016, 12 additional posts were created to fulfill the HKMA's supervisory responsibilities under the new insurance industry regulatory regime. Therefore, the HKMA's staffing structure reached 887 people by the end of 2016.

To ensure sufficient resources to implement new legislation and policies, continue ongoing pilot projects, and handle increasingly complex and demanding work, the overall staffing structure increased by 40 people to 927 in 2017 (an increase of 4.5%). The new positions are responsible for the following functions:
- Promoting banking and financial system stability, including:
    - Enhancing supervisory capabilities to manage increasing technological risks faced by banks and new fintech initiatives, as well as addressing banks' expansion within the region and their business operations;
    - Strengthening anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing regulatory and enforcement efforts, and preparing for the mutual evaluation exercise of the Financial Action Task Force (FATF) in 2018;
    - Planning and preparation for the implementation of the Financial Institutions (Resolution Regime) Ordinance to address the 'too big to fail' issue in the financial sector according to international standards; and
    - Enhancing supervisory capabilities to align with new international standards on capital and market risks, and allocating resources to handle consumer protection matters and bank complaints.
- Strengthening investment, risk management, and other related support due to the increased investment work involved in further promoting diversification of the Exchange Fund's investment products, while strengthening strategic asset allocation and investment processes to cope with the growing investment challenges.
- Developing and implementing human resource development programmes, and enhancing relevant resources to ensure the HKMA has the necessary manpower to meet market developments and future challenges.
- Enhancing monetary policy research and monetary statistics processing, and providing resources to handle inquiries and complaints regarding licensing/designation and related regulatory matters concerning stored value facilities and retail payment systems.

The HKMA allocates temporary resources to deal with other work and transfers staff to international or local organizations, such as the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the Financial Development Council, to assist with work or policies involving Hong Kong or the HKMA. In addition, the HKMA sends staff to the Hong Kong Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Financial Markets Association to provide full-time or supportive operational assistance.

# Remuneration Policies and Remuneration Review Mechanism

The Financial Secretary, through the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, takes into consideration recommendations from its governing committees and refers to market remuneration levels and practices when determining the remuneration and service conditions of HKMA staff. The remuneration package includes cash compensation and mandatory provident fund contributions, along with some basic benefits. Cash compensation comprises monthly fixed compensation (i.e., base salary) and variable compensation paid once a year based on employee performance.

When reviewing the remuneration of HKMA staff annually, the Financial Secretary seeks recommendations from the governing committees through the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, considers the governing committee's assessment of the HKMA's performance over the past year, results of financial industry remuneration surveys conducted by independent human resources consulting companies, and other relevant factors. Individual employees who demonstrate outstanding performance may also receive special adjustments to their remuneration to maintain competitiveness.

The HKMA allocates approved funds for adjusting annual fixed compensation or paying variable compensation based on individual employee performance. The variable compensation scheme for professional investors aims to strengthen the link between investment performance and remuneration. Fixed compensation adjustments or variable compensation payments for Assistant Managing Directors and above are approved by the Financial Secretary after considering the views of the governing committees. These employees will be absent during discussions on their remuneration proposals at meetings. Fixed compensation adjustments or variable compensation payments for managers and below are decided by the HKMA Chief Executive based on the authority granted by the Financial Secretary and the approved lump sum allocated for paying salaries.

其餘5%的該等金融資產的公平值，是以估值方法估計，而所用的參數並非以可觀察市場數據為基礎（第3級參數）。有關金融資產共1,758.86億港元，主要包括非上市投資基金。

鑑於所涉數額龐大及涉及估計，按公平值列帳的金融資產及金 融負債的估值屬關鍵審計事項。

就按公平值列帳的金融資產及金融負債的估值，審計程序包括：
- 了解不同類別金融資產及金融負債的估值程序，包括相關監控措施；
- 評價及測試監控措施，包括電腦系統的相關應用程式監控措施；
- 就金融資產及金融負債的估值、存在、權利與責任及完整性取得函證；
- 若使用市場報價，根據獨立來源核實價格；
- 若所用估值方法的參數是以可觀察市場數據為基礎，評價估值方法是否適合及有關假設是否合理，以及根據獨立來源核實參數；及
- 若所用估值方法的參數並非以可觀察市場數據為基礎，評價估值方法是否適合，以及有關假設與參數是否合理。

# 未來基金存款

請參閱財務報表附註2.6、2.16.1、4(b)、23及28。

在以往年度，財政儲備的絕大部分存款均須於要求時償還，並按每年參考投資組合過去的投資回報釐定的固定息率計算利息。

政府於2016年1月1日在財政儲備內設立未來基金。未來基金存款包含來自土地基金結餘的首筆資金（為數2,197.30億港元），以及從政府一般收入帳目轉撥的恆常注資（金額由財政司司長指示）。未來基金存款的利息按綜合息率計算，而該綜合息率是參考上文提及與投資組合的表現掛鈎的固定息率及與長期增長組合（持有私募股權及房地產投資）的表現掛鈎的年度回報率，每年在加權平均基礎上釐定。除財政司司長另有指示外，未來基金的存款連同所賺取的利息應在2025年12月31日償還。

於2016年12月31日，未來基金的存款共2,245.30億港元。有關存款的累計利息為100.71億港元。由於涉及數額龐大及存款條件有重大改變，需要格外關注有關存款及所賺取的利息的計量、列報方式及披露資料。

就未來基金存款，審計程序包括：
- 評價計量有關存款及所賺取的利息所用的會計政策是否恰當；
- 審視與長期增長組合的表現掛鈎的年度回報率的計算方法；
- 核實參考投資組合以往的表現釐定的固定息率、與長期增長組合的表現掛鈎的年度回報率及參考該兩項息率釐定的綜合息率的計算；
- 核實以綜合息率計算的應計利息數額；及
- 審視有關存款及所賺取的利息在財務報表中的列報方式及披露資料。

# 按公平值列帳的投資物業的估值

請參閱財務報表附註2.12、17及18。

集團的投資物業按公平值列帳，於2016年12月31日共值227.23億港元。集團亦於3間聯營公司及14間合營公司擁有權益，該等公司主要業務為持有海外投資物業，有關權益共值320.83億港元。不論是由集團直接持有或由聯營公司或合營公司持有，該等投資物業的公平值均主要根據獨立專業估值師的估值釐定。該等估值涉及重大判斷及估計，包括所用的估值方法及假設。

就按公平值列帳的投資物業的估值，審計程序包括：
- 獲取及審視由集團直接持有或由聯營公司或合營公司持有的投資物業的估值報告，並核實公平值是根據有關估值報告所列的估值釐定；
- 評估估值師的獨立性及資歷；及
- 評價估值方法是否適合，以及有關假設與參數是否合理。

# 其他資料

金融管理專員須對其他資料負責。其他資料包括金融管理局2016年年報內的所有資料，但不包括財務報表及我的審計師報告。

我對財務報表的意見並不涵蓋其他資料，我亦不對其他資料發表任何形式的鑒證結論。

就財務報表審計而言，我有責任閱讀其他資料，從而考慮其他資料是否與財務報表或我在審計過程中得悉的情況有重大矛盾，或者似乎存有重大錯誤陳述。基於我已執行的工作，如果我認為其他資料存有重大錯誤陳述，我需要報告該事實。在這方面，我沒有任何報告。

# 金融管理專員及外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會就財務報表而須承擔的責任

金融管理專員須負責按照香港會計師公會頒布的《香港財務報告準則》及行政長官在《外匯基金條例》第7條下所發出的指示擬備真實而公平的財務報表，及落實其認為必要的內部控制，使財務報表不存有因欺詐或錯誤而導致的重大錯誤陳述。

在擬備財務報表時，金融管理專員須負責評估集團持續經營的能力， 以及在適用情況下披露與持續經營有關的事項，並以持續經營作為會計基礎。

外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會負責監督集團的財務報告過程。

# 審計師就財務報表審計而須承擔的責任

我的目標是就整體財務報表是否不存有任何因欺詐或錯誤而導致的重大錯誤陳述取得合理保證，並發出包括我意見的審計師報告。合理保證是高水平的保證，但不能確保按審計署審計準則進行的審計定能發現所存有的任何重大錯誤陳述。錯誤陳述可以由欺詐或錯誤引起，如果合理預期它們個別或滙總起來可能影響財務報表使用者所作出的經濟決定，則會被視作重大錯誤陳述。

在根據審計署審計準則進行審計的過程中，我會運用專業判斷並秉持專業懷疑態度。我亦會：
- 識別和評估因欺詐或錯誤而導致財務報表存有重大錯誤陳述的風險；設計及執行審計程序以應對這些風險；以及取得充足和適當的審計憑證，作為我意見的基礎。由於欺詐可能涉及串謀、偽造、蓄意遺漏、虛假陳述，或凌駕內部控制的情況，因此未能發現因欺詐而導致重大錯誤陳述的風險，較未能發現因錯誤而導致者為高；
- 了解與審計相關的內部控制，以設計適當的審計程序。然而，此舉並非旨在對集團內部控制的有效性發表意見；
- 評價金融管理專員所採用的會計政策是否恰當，以及其作出的會計估計和相關資料披露是否合理；
- 判定金融管理專員以持續經營作為會計基礎的做法是否恰當，並根據所得的審計憑證，判定是否存在與事件或情況有關，而且可能對集團持續經營的能力構成重大疑慮的重大不確定性。如果我認為存在重大不確定性，則有必要在審計師報告中請使用者留意財務報表中的相關資料披露。假若所披露的相關資料不足，我便須發出非無保留意見的審計師報告。我的結論是基於截至審計師報告日止所取得的審計憑證。然而，未來事件或情況可能導致集團不能繼續持續經營；
- 評價財務報表的整體列報方式、結構和內容，包括披露資料，以及財務報表是否公允反映交易和事項；及
- 就集團中實體或業務活動的財務資料獲取充足和適當的審計憑證，以對財務報表發表意見。我負責指導、監督和執行集團審計。我對我的審計意見承擔全部責任。

我會與外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會溝通計劃的審計範圍和時間以及重大審計發現等事項，包括我在審計期間識別出內部控制的任何重大缺陷。

# Exchange Fund

# Auditor General's Report

# Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Audit Commission

# Independent Auditor's Report to the Financial Secretary

# Opinion

I hereby certify that I have audited the financial statements of the Exchange Fund and its subsidiaries ("the Group") set out on pages 149 to 237. These financial statements include the balance sheet of the Exchange Fund and the Group as at 31 December 2016, and the income and expenditure accounts, comprehensive income statements, changes in equity statements, and cash flow statements for the year ended on that date, together with the notes to the financial statements, including summaries of significant accounting policies.

In my opinion, these financial statements present fairly the financial position of the Exchange Fund and the Group as at 31 December 2016, and their financial performance and cash flows for the year then ended, in accordance with the Hong Kong Financial Reporting Standards issued by the Hong Kong Institute of Certified Public Accountants, and have been properly prepared in accordance with the instructions issued by the Chief Executive under section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance (Chapter 66).

# Basis of Opinion

The audit was conducted in accordance with the instructions issued by the Chief Executive under section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance and the audit standards of the Audit Commission. My responsibilities relating to the audit of the financial statements are detailed in the section entitled "Responsibilities of the Auditor in Relation to the Audit of the Financial Statements" in this report. Under those standards, I am independent of the Group and have fulfilled other ethical responsibilities in accordance with those standards. I believe that the audit evidence obtained is sufficient and appropriate to support my audit opinion.

# Critical Audit Matters

Critical audit matters are those areas that, in my professional judgment, were most significant in the audit of the financial statements for the year ended 31 December 2016. I addressed these matters in the overall audit and formed an opinion on the financial statements, but I do not provide separate opinions on these matters.

# Auditor General's Report (Continued)

# Critical Audit Matters

How I addressed these matters during the audit

# Valuation of Financial Assets and Liabilities Measured at Fair Value

See Notes 2.5, 2.6 and 36.1 to the financial statements.

As at 31 December 2016, the Group had financial assets measured at fair value amounting to HK$319,897.5 billion and financial liabilities measured at fair value amounting to HK$963,977 million.

95% of these financial assets and all of these financial liabilities were valued based on quoted prices in active markets (Level 1 inputs), or estimated using valuation techniques with parameters based on observable market data (Level 2 inputs).

The remaining 5% of these financial assets were valued using valuation techniques with parameters not based on observable market data (Level 3 inputs). These financial assets amounted to HK$17,588.6 billion, primarily comprising non-listed investment funds.

Given the large amounts involved and the estimation nature of the valuations, the valuation of financial assets and liabilities measured at fair value constitutes a critical audit matter.

Audit procedures related to the valuation of financial assets and liabilities measured at fair value included:
- Understanding the valuation processes for different categories of financial assets and liabilities, including relevant controls;
- Evaluating and testing the controls, including application controls over computer systems;
- Obtaining confirmations regarding the valuation, existence, rights and obligations, and completeness of financial assets and liabilities;
- Verifying prices from independent sources if market quotations were used;
- Evaluating whether the valuation methods were appropriate and the assumptions reasonable, and verifying the parameters from independent sources if the parameters were based on observable market data; and
- Evaluating whether the valuation methods were appropriate, and whether the assumptions and parameters were reasonable, if the parameters were not based on observable market data.

# Future Fund Deposits

See Notes 2.6, 2.16.1, 4(b), 23 and 28 to the financial statements.

In previous years, the majority of deposits in the Government's reserves were repayable upon demand and interest was calculated at a fixed rate determined annually based on the past investment returns of the reference portfolio.

The Government established the Future Fund within the Government's reserves on 1 January 2016. The Future Fund deposits included the initial funding of HK$21,973.0 billion from the Land Fund surplus, as well as regular contributions transferred from the Government's general revenue account (amounts determined by the Financial Secretary). Interest on the Future Fund deposits was calculated using a composite rate, which was determined annually on a weighted average basis, taking into account both the fixed rate linked to the performance of the reference portfolio mentioned above and the annual return rate linked to the long-term growth portfolio (holding private equity and real estate investments). Unless otherwise instructed by the Financial Secretary, the Future Fund deposits together with the interest earned should be repaid by 31 December 2025.

As at 31 December 2016, the Future Fund deposits amounted to HK$22,453.0 billion. The accumulated interest was HK$1,007.1 billion. Due to the large amounts involved and the significant changes in deposit conditions, special attention was required regarding the measurement, presentation, and disclosure of these deposits and the interest earned.

Audit procedures related to the Future Fund deposits included:
- Evaluating whether the accounting policies used to measure the deposits and the interest earned were appropriate;
- Reviewing the methodology for calculating the annual return rates linked to the long-term growth portfolio;
- Verifying the calculations of the fixed rate determined based on the historical performance of the reference portfolio, the annual return rates linked to the long-term growth portfolio, and the composite rate determined based on these two rates;
- Verifying the accrued interest calculated using the composite rate; and
- Reviewing the presentation and disclosure of the deposits and the interest earned in the financial statements.

# Valuation of Investment Properties Measured at Fair Value

See Notes 2.12, 17 and 18 to the financial statements.

The Group's investment properties were measured at fair value and amounted to HK$2,272.3 billion as at 31 December 2016. The Group also held interests in three associate companies and 14 joint ventures, which mainly engaged in holding overseas investment properties, with the interests amounting to HK$3,208.3 billion. Whether directly held by the Group or through associate or joint venture companies, the fair values of these investment properties were primarily determined based on valuations by independent professional valuers. These valuations involved significant judgments and estimates, including the valuation methods and assumptions used.

Audit procedures related to the valuation of investment properties measured at fair value included:
- Obtaining and reviewing the valuation reports for investment properties directly held by the Group or through associate or joint venture companies, and verifying that the fair values were determined based on the valuations stated in these reports;
- Assessing the independence and qualifications of the valuers; and
- Evaluating whether the valuation methods were appropriate and whether the assumptions and parameters were reasonable.

# Other Information

The Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority is responsible for other information. Other information includes all information contained in the Annual Report of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority for 2016, but does not include the financial statements and my auditor's report.

My opinion on the financial statements does not cover other information, and I do not express any form of assurance conclusion on other information.

In relation to the audit of the financial statements, I have a responsibility to read other information to consider whether it is materially inconsistent with the financial statements or the information known during the audit, or appears to contain material misstatements. Based on the work I have performed, if I believe that other information contains material misstatements, I would need to report this fact. In this regard, I have no reports.

# Responsibilities of the Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee in respect of the financial statements

The Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority is responsible for preparing true and fair financial statements in accordance with the Hong Kong Financial Reporting Standards issued by the Hong Kong Institute of Certified Public Accountants and the instructions issued by the Chief Executive under section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance, and implementing internal controls that the Chief Executive considers necessary to prevent material misstatements in the financial statements due to fraud or error.

In preparing the financial statements, the Chief Executive is responsible for assessing the Group's ability to continue as a going concern, and disclosing matters relating to going concern where applicable, and using going concern as the basis of accounting.

The Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee is responsible for overseeing the Group's financial reporting process.

# Responsibilities of the Auditor in Relation to the Audit of the Financial Statements

My objective is to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the overall financial statements are free from material misstatements due to fraud or error and to issue an auditor's report containing my opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance, but it cannot ensure that the audit carried out in accordance with the Audit Commission's audit standards will detect any material misstatements. Material misstatements can arise from fraud or error, and would be considered material if individually or in aggregate they could affect the economic decisions of users of the financial statements.

During the audit conducted in accordance with the Audit Commission's audit standards, I will apply professional judgment and maintain professional skepticism. I will also:
- Identify and assess the risks of material misstatements in the financial statements arising from fraud or error; design and perform audit procedures to address these risks; and obtain sufficient and appropriate audit evidence as the basis for my opinion. Because fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional omission, false representation, or override of internal controls, the risk of not detecting material misstatements arising from fraud is higher than the risk of not detecting those arising from error;
- Understand the internal control relevant to the audit to design appropriate audit procedures. However, this does not constitute an opinion on the effectiveness of the Group's internal controls;
- Evaluate whether the accounting policies adopted by the Chief Executive are appropriate, and whether the accounting estimates and related disclosures are reasonable;
- Determine whether the use of going concern as the basis of accounting by the Chief Executive is appropriate, and based on the audit evidence obtained, determine whether there are material uncertainties related to events or circumstances that may cast significant doubt on the Group's ability to continue as a going concern. If I believe there are material uncertainties, I must draw the users' attention to the relevant disclosures in the financial statements. If the relevant disclosures are insufficient, I must issue an auditor's report with a qualified opinion. My conclusions are based on the audit evidence obtained up to the date of the auditor's report. However, future events or circumstances may cause the Group to be unable to continue as a going concern;
- Evaluate the overall presentation, structure, and content of the financial statements, including disclosures, and whether the financial statements fairly reflect the transactions and events; and
- Obtain sufficient and appropriate audit evidence regarding the financial information of entities or business activities within the Group to form an opinion on the financial statements. I am responsible for directing, supervising, and performing the audit of the Group. I bear full responsibility for my audit opinion.

I will communicate with the Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee regarding the scope and timing of the planned audit and major audit findings, including any significant deficiencies in internal control identified during the audit.
